frameDefinitions: A perceptible Figure shows up against a Ground location due to Light shining on/from it, its salience possibly dependent on a Cause_of_shine.
A Host is judged regarding their attitude as a potential host in a guest-host relationship.
This frame contains verbs that describe emotional experiences and participate in the locative alternation, as in the following examples: '' ' I was boiling with anger.'
An Emitter emits a Beam of light from a Source, along a Path, and/or towards a Goal.
A Cause, animate or inanimate, causes a process, the Effect, to begin.
An Entity changes from a Prior_state to a Post_state in a sequence that follows a pre-defined plan, expectation, or model of change.
frameExamples: I found the board to be very <t>hospitable</t> to Russian graduates.
Avoid allowing light to <t>shine</t> into neighbors' gardens.
The murder of Sergei Kirov <t>set off</t> a chain of events that culminated in the Great Terror of the 1930s.
Their offensive armament has <t>developed</t> from short range missiles to long-range ballistic weaponry in a relatively short period .
listRoleDefinitions: The percept which is perceived at a certain <fen>Ground</fen> location.
The location of the phenomenon.
The <fen>Light</fen> which is emitted.  In this frame, it is usually incorporated in verbs and adjectives, and is the denotation of many of the nouns.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Figure</fen> is observed against the <fen>Ground</fen> location due to <fen>Light</fen> shining on it.
The spatial setting in which the <fen>Figure</fen> shows up against a <fen>Ground</fen> location.
The <fen>Host</fen> is the person whose <fen>Behavior</fen> towards others as a (potential) host is evaluated.
The <fen>Guest</fen> is the entity which is positively or negatively treated by the <fen>Host</fen>.
The <fen>Behavior</fen> is the action of the <fen>Host</fen> on which the evaluation of the <fen>Host</fen>'s character is based.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the situation or person that the <fen>Host</fen>'s <fen>Behavior</fen> responds to or is related to.
The <fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part which indicates the character of the <fen>Host</fen>.
The individual whose point of view is taken in assigning the evaluation.
The Experiencer is the individual that experiences the <fen>Emotion</fen>.

The Emotion experienced (usually restricted to words such as <ment>anger, fury, rage, passion</ment>) can occur as the External Argument or in a PP Complement. Alternatively, there may be no expression of Emotion separate from the target verb:
The words in this frame can occur with an overtly expressed Seat of the Emotion. This frame element occurs as a PP Complement:
This role identifies the entity at the <fen>Source</fen> from which the <fen>Beam</fen> originates.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the location the <fen>Beam</fen> occupies initially before its change of location.
The light that travels from a <fen>Source</fen> along a <fen>Path</fen> to a <fen>Goal</fen>.
<fen>Path</fen> refers to where the <fen>Beam</fen> travels over or to a landmark the <fen>Beam</fen> travels by.
<fen>Goal</fen> is the location the <fen>Beam</fen> ends up in.
An animate or inanimate entity, a force, or event that produces an effect. Volitionality is not a necessary characteristic of <fen>Cause</fen>s.
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate the process that the <fen>Cause</fen> initiates.
This role is for the <fen>Time</fen>  when causing to start occurs
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Effect</fen> occurs.
The object that undergoes change.
The time at which the progress occurs.
The location where the Progress occurs.
listRoleExamples: Hot coals glowed <fex>behind the fire grate</fex>.
<fex>In the morning</fex> the grass glistened with dew
<fex>Outside</fex> something was shimmering on the shore.
<fex>Sunlight</fex> gleamed from the water of the bay.
Few things spark <fex>the wrath of the British</fex> like food additives.
<fex>In Obscurania</fex>, the release of the movie sparked protests.
Advances <fex>in marketing techniques</fex> have since rendered it obsolete.
<fex>When</fex> did the X-wing progress beyond the drawing board?

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the first nine months of this year
